experience.description: Developing cutting edge magnetometer solutions for industrial applications at the Quantum Research Center.

Developed computational simulations of diamond geometry to determine the optimal number of 13C nuclear spins for quantum information processing. Investigated hyperfine interactions with NV- electrons, spin flip rates, and the influence of magnetic fields on spin orientation, optimizing configurations for quantum applications.

projects_topics: Quantum Sensing for GPS independent Navigation
Quantum Circuit synthesis for approximate No-Cloning theorem Violation
Evaluation of Suitability of 13Carbon atoms for NV center based Quantum Information Processing in Diamond

projects.name: Quantum Sensing for GPS independent Navigation
projects.description: Developed as part of the Quantum Entrepreneurship Laboratory course at TUM Venture Labs, this project focused on building a GNSS-independent navigation framework by fusing a quantum magnetometer with an inertial navigation system using a hybrid EKF and Earth magnetic anomaly maps (EMAG v2). Implemented robust magnetic map-matching with bilinear interpolation, gradient-based gating, and consistency checks. Ran extensive Monte-Carlo simulations of linear, circular, and oscillatory flight paths to quantify drift, map-resolution limits, correction cadence, and sensor-noise effects. Demonstrated through simulation that sub-10 nT quantum magnetometer noise enables < 100 m RMS 2D positioning accuracy, validating the feasibility of quantum magnetic navigation. Co-authored a technical paper and contributed to the entrepreneurial development of a quantum-navigation startup concept, including market analysis, value-proposition design, and pitching to quantum technology and venture experts. Show less

projects.name: Quantum Max-Cut Optimization using Cirq
projects.description: Implemented the Max-Cut problem using Cirq as part of the QNickel quantum optimization workshop series. Designed quantum circuits to encode graph cuts, constructed oracles to evaluate cut sizes, and applied Grover‚Äôs algorithm to find maximum cuts in small graphs. Emphasized oracle design, circuit reversibility, and uncomputation techniques. Gained hands-on experience with quantum algorithms for combinatorial optimization.

projects.name: Quantum Circuit synthesis for approximate No-Cloning theorem Violation
projects.description: Hackathon organized by PushQuantum brought together talented students from various countries to participate in the challenges offered by three companies in the Quantum Industry. Quandella was the provider of the above challenge where we had to use their python package Perceval to create photonic quantum computing circuits.

projects.name: Evaluation of Suitability of 13Carbon atoms for NV center based Quantum Information Processing in Diamond
projects.description: This thesis aims to estimate the extent of scalability of a quantum processor based on NV centers in diamond by calculating the maximum number of 13C nuclear spins that can be utilized for quantum information processing. By simulating a precise diamond geometry, we present theoretical examinations of hyperfine interaction between a 13C nuclear spins and an NV- electron to study the properties of weakly and strongly coupled nuclear spins, such as its spatial distribution and its total count in a given lattice. Furthermore, we perform studies based on such a framework on the spin flip rate of a 13C by virtue of electron flips as well as the direction of nuclear spin axis, a 13C spin assumes due to the influence of an external magnetic field and a dipole magnetic field of the NV- electron. Based on a given hyperfine threshold and minimum angle of nuclear spin condition, we define the criteria for a suitable 13C spin and evaluate its count, properties and statistical variations through the generation of 1000 diamond supercell lattices and also in its optimal configuration which yielded a total of 22 13C spin at 2 T of external magnetic field. Show less

projects.name: Galilean Cannon
projects.description: Computer simulation to describe the kinematics that describe the high energy behavior of cosmic rays observed from stars.
